Maximus of Tyre Dissertationsz Anacreon, the poet of Teos, is said to have been punished by Love in the following way. One day at the Pan-Ionian Festival a nurse was carrying a baby in the Ionian Meeting-Place,2 when Anacreon came along tipsy and shouting with a wreath on his head, and stumbling against the woman and her charge let sall some words of abuse. The indignant nurse con- tented herself with expressing a pious wish that the very scoundrel who now cursed the child should live to praise him in still stronger ternis—which indeed was the fact 3 for the God heard her prayer and, the child growing to be the lovely Cleobulus, Anacreon expiated a little curse with manifold praise.
